children.subject: I have heard that physics 112 is too basic (similar to how you are describing 137A).  Hence, jumping to graduate physics.

The difficulty for 112 can range based on professor but you would probably want to know QM 137A&B to understand the subject at its full potential. For instance, you would want to know the difference between bosons and fermions.

I had 112 with Charman, and it was definitely not too basic.  Generally, from what I've heard, Charman is definitely a hard professor, and the class is difficult, but you'll definitely learn a lot.  I more or less agree with the other anon's evaluation of 137A (if you're interested in the material, Griffith's is a pretty good text), though there is some stuff with Hamiltonians that might be new, depending on what math you've had.  Also, like the other anon, I would advise against taking graduate physics classes unless you know what you're doing.

If you want a good hard physics class, take it with a professor name andrew charman. You will gain some mental muscle.

As for 137A, the class is relatively chill. By no means I am saying QM is easy. It's just the fact that 137A is an intro course so we only end up doing 4 chapters of griffith where the first chapter shouldn't even be counted. You will see probability and linear algebra but they are nothing new. The interesting part is applying them to see facts like energy levels in the hydrogen level are discrete, the concept of schrodinger's cat, tunneling, and perhaps demystifying all the "orbital stuff" learned in chemistry class. The class is obviously not always intuitive and since the most models are too complex to solve using schrodingers eq, many crude approximations are made to solve very limited number of models such as particle in a box, harmonic oscillator and the hydrogen atom. 

I would advise against taking a graduate physics course if you haven't taken any upper div physics courses unless you know what you are doing.

I personally don't really see a reason to take extra physics classes when there are so many upper div math/ EE courses that are more relevant to what you will be doing in ML/AI, but that's just my opinion. Some ideas from statistical mechanics and control-like parts of physics are used though

history.content: If you wanna build problem solving skills take upperdiv Math class, EE 120 series or CS 170 series.
If you wanna build problem solving skills take upperdiv Math class, EE 120 series or CS 170 series.

@Anant Sahai noted the importance of physics in @4690.

Which physics courses most directly exercise the mental muscles described?

Curious about:

137A: Quantum Mechanics - Linear algebra and probability intuition?

211: Equilibrium Stat Phys - stat/prob intuition?

Others? http://guide.berkeley.edu/courses/physics/

Update: I ask under the scenario that one has already essentially taken all obvious options in EECS and Math.
history.subject: Physics classes to build problem-solving abilities in EECS?
